texts.definition: Game elements used as tools to cause death and destruction in game worlds.
markups: <style="Definition">Game elements used as tools to cause death and destruction in game worlds.</style>

Many games have combat as a core mechanic in them. To provide players with variety in how this is done and let them become more and more powerful, many games let them get access to <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style>. These let the players  become more efficient in various aspects of combat and can let them consider various tactical and strategic advantages of which <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> they will employ.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roleplaying%20Games">Roleplaying Games</link></style> often contain large numbers of weapons and extensive rules for these, see for example <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mutant">Mutant</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style>. Many of these include rules for improving them through additional hardware or magic (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style>) and deterioration through use of neglect (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mutant">Mutant</link></style>). For <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop varieties</link></style> there often exist entire books with additional <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> and rules for them<ref name="GDW1"/><ref name="SJ1"/><ref name="SJ2"/><ref name="SJ3"/><ref name="SJ4"/>.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Adventure">Adventure</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Gun.Smoke">Gun.Smoke</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Metal%20Slug%20series">Metal Slug series</link></style> are all examples of 2D computer games in which players can find <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> during gameplay. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">First-person shooters</link></style> such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%20series">Doom</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Crysis%20series">Crysis series</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Grand%20Theft%20Auto%20series">Grand Theft Auto series</link></style> let players find many types of <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> and knowing which work best against which enemies is often part of the strategic knowledge possible for the games. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bioshock%20series">Bioshock</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Deus%20Ex%20series">Deus Ex</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> also do this but provide possibilities to upgrade weapons in different ways. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Crysis%20series">Crysis</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Just%20Cause%20series">Just Cause</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Metal%20Slug%20series">Metal Slug series</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Enemy%20Territory:%20Quake%20Wars">Enemy Territory: Quake Wars</link></style> all lets players use vehicles that provide heavy weapons (as do a few vehicles in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Grand%20Theft%20Auto%20series">Grand Theft Auto series</link></style>). The gravity gun in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Half-Life%202">Half-Life 2</link></style> and grappling hook <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Just%20Cause%202">Just Cause 2</link></style> show how tools can be used as efficient improvised weapons. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zombie%20Lane">Zombie Lane</link></style> show that <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> can be important in other types of games also.

<style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> are a type of <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, and designing <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> consist of considering how one wants to change how <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> can engage in <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>, and this may be through <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style>. Increased <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> is probably the most obvious examples of <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style> and this may of course differ between different <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> but other examples include increased speed, accuracy (i.e. making <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> more easy), chance of getting <style="Link"><link="critical-hits">Critical Hits</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="critical-misses">Critical Misses</link></style>, or the range of attacks (one can also say that <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> create <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> to be possible in games). What constitutes <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> of course depend on what is the norm but common examples include ranged attacks when this is not the norm (e.g. bows in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style>) which instantiates a need for <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> actions, forcing <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> through stuns, changing <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style> (e.g. the ''Mesmetron'' in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%203">Fallout 3</link></style>), or giving <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style>. By controlling which have access to these <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> they can also be <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>. The various <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> may of course be combined. <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> are <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, or even <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> diegetically intended mainly as <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> (e.g. the gravity gun in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Half-Life%202">Half-Life 2</link></style> and the grappling hook in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Just%20Cause%202">Just Cause 2</link></style>) but some non-tangible game design solutions, e.g. spells, have many similarities and may be considered as alternatives to <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style>.

Several common options exist of the design of <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style>. The most common for ranged weapons is probably having <style="Link"><link="crosshairs">Crosshairs</link></style> followed by <style="Link"><link="ammunition">Ammunition</link></style> as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="ammunition">Ammunition</link></style> restrictions are however often wavered for the most basic <style="CurrentLink">Weapon</style> (examples of this include the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%20series">Doom</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Crysis%20series">Crysis series</link></style>, as well as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zombie%20Lane">Zombie Lane</link></style>). This may also be present in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> depending on how much bookkeeping (and <style="Link"><link="excise">Excise</link></style>) players and <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> wish to perform. An alternative to <style="Link"><link="ammunition">Ammunition</link></style>, which can be combined with it, is using <style="Link"><link="cooldown">Cooldown</link></style> periods. Having different <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> provide different attack types is a way of making use of <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style> in games, and is done for example in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20and%20Dragons">Dungeons and Dragons</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="deterioration">Deterioration</link></style> by use is found in several games, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mutant">Mutant</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style>, and make individual <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> into <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style> and may motivate <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style> to maintain their usefulness.  <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Upgrading">Upgrading</link></style> different aspects of <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> such as accuracy (in games that have <style="Link"><link="variable-accuracy">Variable Accuracy</link></style>), <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style>, weight, and ammunition limits, can be motivated by adding additional <style="Link"><link="upgrades">Upgrades</link></style> such as scopes and extended magazines (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style>), through inserting magical gems (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style>), or simply magical spells and rituals (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>). <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> can also be created to be  parts of <style="Link"><link="sets">Sets</link></style> - typically either <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style>-only <style="Link"><link="sets">Sets</link></style> or mixtures of <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> and <style="Link"><link="armor">Armor</link></style>. While some <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> can be used as improvised <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> (e.g. the grappling hook in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Just%20Cause%202">Just Cause 2</link></style>), it worth considering if <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> can be used as improvised <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> (swords can for example be used to "mine" sand and wood in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style>). The ''rocket'' <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Jumping">Jumping</link></style> in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake series</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Fortress%20Classic">Team Fortress Classic</link></style> (including medics' concussion grenade <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Jumping">Jumping</link></style> for the latter), show that <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> can be used to provide <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style> also.

Another aspect of <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style>, like all <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, is how players should be hold of them. Common ways of providing <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> to players are as <style="Link"><link="loot">Loot</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style>, or through <style="Link"><link="unlocking">Unlocking</link></style> them. However, some types of <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> are not suitable for this. <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style> are one example of this due to existing as independent parts of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. Their immobility is typically compensated by providing <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> on a different scale than other <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style>. <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style> can diegetically motivate weapons of the same caliber as <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style> and also typically exist independently in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> (they can also be <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> in their own right if one can cause <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> by running into other game elements). However, <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style> may even more than other ways of providing <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> negatively affect <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> since they also improve <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> (or provide <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style>) and potentially <style="Link"><link="armor">Armor</link></style> as well. For games with <style="Link"><link="endgame">Endgame</link></style> phases, unique <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> may be part of the <style="Link"><link="loot">Loot</link></style> provided in <style="Link"><link="endgame-quests">Endgame Quests</link></style> to keep the opportunity for development possible for some time in these phases.

<style="Link"><link="equipment-slots">Equipment Slots</link></style> can be used to limit the number of <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> players can have by restricting them to a few of each type. When not restricted in this way, <style="Link"><link="equipment-slots">Equipment Slots</link></style> can instead serve as the way of showing which <style="CurrentLink">Weapon</style> one is currently armed with.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Avatar%20Personalization">Avatar Personalization</link></style> can be used to indicate which <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> players have, both for themselves and for other players.

Like for <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, the construction of <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> for games with <style="Link"><link="live-action-roleplaying">Live Action Roleplaying</link></style> may need to be the construction of replicas of real world <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style>.

Magical or otherwise powerful <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> have played important roles as <style="Link"><link="macguffins">MacGuffins</link></style> in many traditional stories, and can likewise do so in games.

<style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> are <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> that serve as <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> for <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>, and thereby are <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> unless only one type exists. By providing either <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style> (possibly <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged ones</link></style>) not being inherent parts of players' abilities to affect games, they are <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style>. This is especially true when their <style="Link"><link="ammunition">Ammunition</link></style> is a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style> as well, or they suffer from <style="Link"><link="deterioration">Deterioration</link></style>. Those targeting <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style> or providing extra <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> to targets with specific <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style> encourages <style="Link"><link="strategic-planning">Strategic Planning</link></style> in selecting <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> in advance of <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style> in selecting them during <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>. Having knowledge about these details are <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style> for players where this is possible.

Since <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> improve <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> abilities in <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>, they are a basis for creating <style="Link"><link="player-character-skill-composites">Player/Character Skill Composites</link></style>.

Games with several different types of <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> provide a natural basis for implementing <style="Link"><link="variable-accuracy">Variable Accuracy</link></style> - they may also be modified by <style="Link"><link="variable-accuracy">Variable Accuracy</link></style> to simulate the need to take time to aim.

When they provide <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style>, they also provide <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style> and a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>. They also serve as <style="Link"><link="facilitating-rewards">Facilitating Rewards</link></style> when being given out during gameplay. Like <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, they can support <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style> in both <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> (by letting different <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> specialize) and <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>. If new <style="CurrentLink">Weapons</style> do not give explicit advantages compared to existing ones, they are likely to be examples of <style="Link"><link="sidegrades">Sidegrades</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="facilitating-rewards">Facilitating Rewards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="macguffins">MacGuffins</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-character-skill-composites">Player/Character Skill Composites</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sets">Sets</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sidegrades">Sidegrades</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="variable-accuracy">Variable Accuracy</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="ammunition">Ammunition</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="cooldown">Cooldown</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="crosshairs">Crosshairs</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="deterioration">Deterioration</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="endgame-quests">Endgame Quests</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="equipment-slots">Equipment Slots</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="live-action-roleplaying">Live Action Roleplaying</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="loot">Loot</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="unlocking">Unlocking</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="upgrades">Upgrades</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Upgrading">Upgrading</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="variable-accuracy">Variable Accuracy</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style>
